an6.1:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an6.1:4.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an6.1:5.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant with six factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.
an6.1:5.3: It’s a mendicant who, when they see a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
an6.1:5.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
an6.1:5.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
an6.1:5.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
an6.1:5.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
an6.1:5.8: When they know a phenomenon with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
an6.1:5.9: A mendicant with these six factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.”
an6.1:6.1: This is what the Buddha said.
an6.1:6.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
